In my career, I've had the privilege of working with some of the most talented individuals in the trade, and I've learned that recruiting the right team is just as crucial as planning the heist itself.

First and foremost, I rely on my extensive network of contacts, forged over years of working in the shadows. I've built relationships with fellow professionals who share my passion for the craft, and I know I can trust them to deliver. I'm not looking for amateurs or thrill-seekers; I need experts who can handle the pressure and complexity of a high-stakes burglary.

I want to know their strengths and weaknesses, their motivations, and their limits. I've worked with safecrackers, hackers, drivers, and inside men - each with their unique expertise and quirks. I need to know that they can perform under pressure, that they can think on their feet, and that they can keep their cool in the face of unexpected complications.

I'm cautious, always mindful of the risks of infiltration or betrayal. I use coded language, vague references, and misdirection to keep our conversations ambiguous, even to those who might be listening.

I brief them on the job, sharing only the essential details, and I emphasize the importance of discretion and loyalty. I make it clear that we're a team, that we rely on each other, and that we'll share the risks and rewards equally.
